                          Euler angles

                          参考：Euler angles From Wikipedia

                          Euler angles to Rotation matrix

                          Any orientation can be achieved by composing three elemental rotations, starting from a known standard orientation.

                          (1)Rx(θ)=[1000cos⁡θ−sin⁡θ0sin⁡θcos⁡θ]Ry(θ)=[cos⁡θ0sin⁡θ010−sin⁡θ0cos⁡θ]Rz(θ)=[cos⁡θ−sin⁡θ0sin⁡θcos⁡θ0001]
                          1
                          根据具体的坐标系定义来确定旋转元素的符号，常见定义为右手系，东北天或东北地。

                          Equivalently, any rotation matrix R can be decomposed as a product of three elemental rotation matrices. For instance:

                          (2)R=X(α)Y(β)Z(γ)

                          is a rotation matrix that may be used to represent a composition of extrinsic rotations about axes z, y, x, (in that order), or a composition of intrinsic rotations about axes x-y′-z″ (in that order). However, both the definition of the elemental rotation matrices X, Y, Z, and their multiplication order depend on the choices taken by the user about the definition of both rotation matrices and Euler angles.

                          xxxxxxxxxx
                          3
                          1
                          外旋(extrinsic rotations)、内旋（intrinsic rotations）是指旋转的参考坐标轴不同，左乘（pre-multiplying）意味着外旋，相对固定坐标系旋转，右乘（Post-multiplication）意味着内旋，相对自身坐标系旋转。无论是欧拉角到旋转矩阵，还是反过来，具体的使用都得看定义；
                          2
                          主动（active）、被动（passive）旋转是指旋转主体是定坐标系还是物体本身（或动坐标系、向量）,这种旋转矩阵的规定，使得这两种物理意义是不冲突的,只是表达形式和理解上的区别;
                          3
                          经典欧拉角（Proper Euler angles）和泰特布莱恩角（Tait–Bryan angles）是指旋转的次序不同，前者的一三轴相同，后者三轴都不同。

                          参考：知乎：旋转的左乘与右乘、主动与被动⭐

                          参考：《机器人学建模、规划与控制》Page 32

                          Unfortunately, different sets of conventions are adopted by users in different contexts. The following table was built according to this set of conventions:

                          1. Each matrix is meant to operate by pre-multiplying column vectors [xyz]T (see Ambiguities in the definition of rotation matrices)
                          2. Each matrix is meant to represent an active rotation (the composing and composed matrices are supposed to act on the coordinates of vectors defined in the initial fixed reference frame and give as a result the coordinates of a rotated vector defined in the same reference frame).
                          3. Each matrix is meant to represent, primarily, a composition of intrinsic rotations (around the axes of the rotating reference frame) and, secondarily, the composition of three extrinsic rotations (which corresponds to the constructive evaluation of the R matrix by the multiplication of three truly elemental matrices, in reverse order).
                          4. Right handed reference frames are adopted, and the right hand rule is used to determine the sign of the angles α,β,γ.

                          For the sake of simplicity, the following table of matrix products uses the following nomenclature:

                          1. 1, 2, 3 represent the angles α,β,γ, i.e. the angles corresponding to the first, second and third elemental rotations respectively.
                          2. X,Y,Z are the matrices representing the elemental rotations about the axes x, y, z of the fixed frame (e.g., X1 represents a rotation about x by an angle α ).
                          3. s and c represent sin and cos (e.g., s1 represents the sine of α).
                          xxxxxxxxxx
                          1
                          1
                          右列最后一行，既可看做zxy的内旋（右乘，自身坐标系），也可以看作yxz的外旋（左乘，固定坐标系），看具体定义可配凑转换为欧拉角。

                          These tabular results are available in numerous textbooks. For each column the last row constitutes the most commonly used convention.

                          To change the formulas for passive rotations (or find reverse active rotation), transpose the matrices (then each matrix transforms the initial coordinates of a vector remaining fixed to the coordinates of the same vector measured in the rotated reference system; same rotation axis, same angles, but now the coordinate system rotates, rather than the vector).

                          Euler angles to Quaternions

                          xxxxxxxxxx
                          1
                          1
                          基本思路：与欧拉角构造旋转矩阵思路一致，根据欧拉角写出基础变换的四元数，然后利用四元数乘法计算。

                          By combining the quaternion representations of the Euler rotations we get for the Body 3-2-1 sequence, where the airplane first does yaw (Body-Z) turn during taxiing onto the runway, then pitches (Body-Y) during take-off, and finally rolls (Body-X) in the air. The resulting orientation of Body 3-2-1 sequence (around the capitalized axis in the illustration of Tait–Bryan angles) is equivalent to that of lab 1-2-3 sequence (around the lower-cased axis), where the airplane is rolled first (lab-x axis), and then nosed up around the horizontal lab-y axis, and finally rotated around the vertical lab-z axis (lB = lab2Body):

                          (3)qlB=[cos⁡(ψ/2)00sin⁡(ψ/2)][cos⁡(θ/2)0sin⁡(θ/2)0][cos⁡(ϕ/2)sin⁡(ϕ/2)00]=[cos⁡(ϕ/2)cos⁡(θ/2)cos⁡(ψ/2)+sin⁡(ϕ/2)sin⁡(θ/2)sin⁡(ψ/2)sin⁡(ϕ/2)cos⁡(θ/2)cos⁡(ψ/2)−cos⁡(ϕ/2)sin⁡(θ/2)sin⁡(ψ/2)cos⁡(ϕ/2)sin⁡(θ/2)cos⁡(ψ/2)+sin⁡(ϕ/2)cos⁡(θ/2)sin⁡(ψ/2)cos⁡(ϕ/2)cos⁡(θ/2)sin⁡(ψ/2)−sin⁡(ϕ/2)sin⁡(θ/2)cos⁡(ψ/2)]

                          Other rotation sequences use different conventions.

                          Axis-angle to Rotation matrix

                          xxxxxxxxxx
                          1
                          1
                          基本思路：向量分解为垂直和平行于旋转轴的两个部分，分别旋转再求和。

                          Let k be a unit vector defining a rotation axis, and let v be any vector to rotate about k by angle θ (right hand rule, anticlockwise in the figure).

                          Using the dot and cross products, the vector v can be decomposed into components parallel and perpendicular to the axis k

                          (4)v=v∥+v⊥

                          where the component parallel to k is

                          (5)v∥=(v⋅k)k

                          called the vector projection of v on k, and the component perpendicular to k is

                          (6)v⊥=v−v∥=v−(k⋅v)k=−k×(k×v)

                          called the vector rejection of v from k.

                          The vector k × v can be viewed as a copy of v⊥ rotated anticlockwise by 90° about k, so their magnitudes are equal but directions are perpendicular. Likewise the vector k × (k × v) a copy of v⊥ rotated anticlockwise through 180° about k, so that k × (k × v) and v⊥ are equal in magnitude but in opposite directions (i.e. they are negatives of each other, hence the minus sign). Expanding the vector triple product establishes the connection between the parallel and perpendicular components, for reference the formula is a × (b × c) = (a · c)b − (a · b)c given any three vectors a, b, c.

                          The component parallel to the axis will not change magnitude nor direction under the rotation,

                          (7)v∥rot=v∥,

                          only the perpendicular component will change direction but retain its magnitude, according to

                          (8)|v⊥rot|=|v⊥|,v⊥rot=cos⁡(θ)v⊥+sin⁡(θ)k×v⊥,

                          and since k and v∥ are parallel, their cross product is zero k × v∥ = 0, so that

                          (9)k×v⊥=k×(v−v∥)=k×v−k×v∥=k×v

                          and it follows

                          (10)v⊥rot=cos⁡(θ)v⊥+sin⁡(θ)k×v.

                          This rotation is correct since the vectors v⊥ and k × v have the same length, and k × v is v⊥ rotated anticlockwise through 90° about k. An appropriate scaling of v⊥ and k × v using the trigonometric functions sine and cosine gives the rotated perpendicular component. The form of the rotated component is similar to the radial vector in 2D planar polar coordinates (r, θ) in the Cartesian basis

                          (11)r=rcos⁡(θ)ex+rsin⁡(θ)ey,

                          where e*x, ey* are unit vectors in their indicated directions.

                          Now the full rotated vector is

                          (12)vrot=v∥rot+v⊥rot,

                          By substituting the definitions of v∥rot and v⊥rot in the equation results in

                          (13)vrot=v∥+cos⁡(θ)v⊥+sin⁡(θ)k×v=v∥+cos⁡(θ)(v−v∥)+sin⁡(θ)k×v=cos⁡(θ)v+(1−cos⁡θ)v∥+sin⁡(θ)k×v=cos⁡(θ)v+(1−cos⁡θ)(k⋅v)k+sin⁡(θ)k×v
                          (14)P×(Q×P)=P×Q×P=P2Q−(P⋅Q)PP×Q=−Q×P
                          (15)vrot=cos⁡(θ)v+(1−cos⁡θ)(k⋅v)k+sin⁡(θ)k×v=cos⁡(θ)v+(1−cos⁡θ)(k2v−k×(v×k))+sin⁡(θ)k×v=v+(1−cos⁡θ)(−k×(v×k))+sin⁡(θ)k×v=v+(1−cos⁡θ)(k×(k×v))+sin⁡(θ)k×v

                           

                          This can be written more concisely as

                          (16)R=(cos⁡θ)I+(sin⁡θ)[u]×+(1−cos⁡θ)(u⊗u),

                          Representing v and k × v as column matrices, the cross product can be expressed as a matrix product

                          (17)[(k×v)x(k×v)y(k×v)z]=[kyvz−kzvykzvx−kxvzkxvy−kyvx]=[0−kzkykz0−kx−kykx0][vxvyvz].

                          Letting K denote the "cross-product matrix" for the unit vector k,

                          (18)K=[k×]=[0−kzkykz0−kx−kykx0],

                          that is to say,

                          (19)Kv=k×v

                          for any vector v. (In fact, K is the unique matrix with this property. It has eigenvalues 0 and ±i).

                          It follows that iterating the cross product is equivalent to multiplying by the cross-product matrix on the left; specifically:

                          (20)K(Kv)=K2v=k×(k×v).

                          The previous rotation formula in matrix language is therefore

                          (21)vrot=vcos⁡θ+(k×v)sin⁡θ+k (k⋅v)(1−cos⁡θ)=vcos⁡θ+(k×v)sin⁡θ+(v−v⊥)(1−cos⁡θ)=vcos⁡θ+(k×v)sin⁡θ+(v+k×(k×v))(1−cos⁡θ)=vcos⁡θ+(k×v)sin⁡θ+(v+K(Kv))(1−cos⁡θ)=v(cos⁡θ+1−cos⁡θ)+(k×v)sin⁡θ+K(Kv)(1−cos⁡θ)

                          So we have:

                          (22)vrot=v+(sin⁡θ)Kv+(1−cos⁡θ)K2v,∥K∥2=1.

                          Note the coefficient of the leading term is now 1, in this notation: see the Lie-Group discussion below.

                          Factorizing the v allows the compact expression

                          (23)vrot=Rv

                          where

                          (24)R=I+(sin⁡θ)K+(1−cos⁡θ)K2

                          is the rotation matrix through an angle θ counterclockwise about the axis k, and I the 3 × 3 identity matrix. This matrix R is an element of the rotation group SO(3) of ℝ3, and K is an element of the Lie algebra so(3) generating that Lie group (note that K is skew-symmetric, which characterizes so(3).

                          The matrix of a proper rotation R by angle θ around the axis u=(ux,uy,uz), a unit vector with ux2+uy2+uz2=1, is given by:

                          (25)R=[cos⁡θ+ux2(1−cos⁡θ)uxuy(1−cos⁡θ)−uzsin⁡θuxuz(1−cos⁡θ)+uysin⁡θuyux(1−cos⁡θ)+uzsin⁡θcos⁡θ+uy2(1−cos⁡θ)uyuz(1−cos⁡θ)−uxsin⁡θuzux(1−cos⁡θ)−uysin⁡θuzuy(1−cos⁡θ)+uxsin⁡θcos⁡θ+uz2(1−cos⁡θ)]

                          参考：四元数和旋转(Quaternion & rotation)

                          Axis-angle to Quaternions

                          The following expression transforms axis–angle coordinates to versors (unit quaternions):

                          (26)Q(ω,v)=(cos⁡θ2,vsin⁡θ2)

                          Rotation matrix to Axis-angle

                          xxxxxxxxxx
                          1
                          1
                          基本思路：根据轴角转换为旋转矩阵的形式，利用已知旋转矩阵的项配凑。

                          To retrieve the axis–angle representation of a rotation matrix, calculate the angle of rotation from the trace of the rotation matrix

                          (27)θ=arccos⁡(Tr⁡(R)−12)

                          and then use that to find the normalized axis,

                          (28)ω=12sin⁡θ[R32−R23R13−R31R21−R12] ,

                          where Rij is the component of the rotation matrix,R, in thei-th row and j-th column. Note that the axis-angle representation is not unique since a rotation of −θabout −ωis the same as a rotation of θ about ω.

                          The above calculation of axis vector ω does not work if R is symmetric. For the general case the ω may be found using null space of R−I.

                          Rotation matrix to Quaternions

                          xxxxxxxxxx
                          1
                          1
                          基本思想：根据四元数转旋转矩阵的形式，对已知的旋转矩阵的项进行配凑，可以求解出四元数的四个量。

                          亦可参考：四元数和旋转(Quaternion & rotation)的推导。

                          Firstly, you should read Quaternions to Rotation matrix.

                          The sum of the entries along the main diagonal (the trace), plus one, equals 4 − 4(x2+y2+z2), which is 4w2. Thus we can write the trace itself as 2w2+2w2−1; and from the previous version of the matrix we see that the diagonal entries themselves have the same form: 2x2+2w2−1, 2y2+2w2−1, and 2z2+2w2−1. So we can easily compare the magnitudes of all four quaternion components using the matrix diagonal. We can, in fact, obtain all four magnitudes using sums and square roots, and choose consistent signs using the skew-symmetric part of the off-diagonal entries:

                          (29)t=tr⁡Q=Qxx+Qyy+Qzz(the trace of Q)r=1+tw=12rx=sgn⁡(Qzy−Qyz)|121+Qxx−Qyy−Qzz|y=sgn⁡(Qxz−Qzx)|121−Qxx+Qyy−Qzz|z=sgn⁡(Qyx−Qxy)|121−Qxx−Qyy+Qzz|

                          Alternatively, use a single square root and division

                          (30)t=tr⁡Q=Qxx+Qyy+Qzzr=1+ts=12rw=12rx=(Qzy−Qyz)sy=(Qxz−Qzx)sz=(Qyx−Qxy)s

                          This is numerically stable so long as the trace, t, is not negative; otherwise, we risk dividing by (nearly) zero. In that case, suppose Qxx is the largest diagonal entry, so x will have the largest magnitude (the other cases are derived by cyclic permutation); then the following is safe.

                          (31)r=1+Qxx−Qyy−Qzzs=12rw=(Qzy−Qyz)sx=12ry=(Qxy+Qyx)sz=(Qzx+Qxz)s

                          If the matrix contains significant error, such as accumulated numerical error, we may construct a symmetric 4 × 4 matrix,

                          (32)K=13[Qxx−Qyy−QzzQyx+QxyQzx+QxzQzy−QyzQyx+QxyQyy−Qxx−QzzQzy+QyzQxz−QzxQzx+QxzQzy+QyzQzz−Qxx−QyyQyx−QxyQzy−QyzQxz−QzxQyx−QxyQxx+Qyy+Qzz],

                          and find the eigenvector, (x, y, z, w), of its largest magnitude eigenvalue. (If Q is truly a rotation matrix, that value will be 1.) The quaternion so obtained will correspond to the rotation matrix closest to the given matrix (Bar-Itzhack 2000) (Note: formulation of the cited article is post-multiplied, works with row vectors).

                          Quaternions to Axis-angle

                          xxxxxxxxxx
                          1
                          1
                          基本思路：根据四元数的形式里面包含了旋转角度和旋转轴，很容易求出轴角。

                          Given a versor q=s+x represented with its scalar s=cos⁡θ2 and vector x=sin⁡θ2[ωx,ωy,ωz]T, the axis–angle coordinates can be extracted using the following:

                          (33)θ=2arccos⁡sω={xsin⁡θ2,if θ≠00,otherwise.

                          A more numerically stable expression of the rotation angle uses the atan2 function:

                          (34)θ=2atan2⁡(|x|,s),

                          where |x| is the Euclidean norm of the 3-vector x.

                          Quaternions to Euler angle

                          Suggest Quaternions to Rotation matrix, then Rotation matrix to Euler angle.

                          The Euler angles can be obtained from the quaternions via the relations:

                          (35)[ϕθψ]=[arctan2(q0q1+q2q3)1−2(q12+q22)arcsin(2(q0q2−q3q1))arctan2(q0q3+q1q2)1−2(q22+q32)]

                          Note, however, that the arctan and arcsin functions implemented in computer languages only produce results between −π/2 and π/2, and for three rotations between −π/2 and π/2 one does not obtain all possible orientations. To generate all the orientations one needs to replace the arctan functions in computer code by atan2:

                          (36)[ϕθψ]=[atan2(2(q0q1+q2q3),1−2(q12+q22))asin(2(q0q2−q3q1))atan2(2(q0q3+q1q2),1−2(q22+q32))]

                          Quaternions to Rotation matrix

                          xxxxxxxxxx
                          1
                          1
                          基本思想：将四元数旋转操作写成矩阵形式，即p'=qpq^-1。

                          Given the unit quaternion

                          (37)q=w+xi+yj+zk=(w,x,y,z)ω2+x2+y2+z2=1

                          不同的表达方式有

                          (38)q0=a=ωq1=b=xq2=c=yq3=d=z

                          四元数的矩阵表达形式推导

                          (39)q1q2=ae+afi+agj+ahk+bei−bf+bgk−bhj+cej−cfk−cg+chi+dek+dfj−dgi−dh=(ae−bf−cg−dh)+(be+af−dg+ch)i+(ce+df+ag−bh)j+(de−cf+bg+ah)k=[a−b−c−dba−dccda−bd−cba][efgh]

                          左乘和右乘四元数的矩阵形式

                          (40)L(q)=[a−b−c−dba−dccda−bd−cba]R(q)=[a−b−c−dbad−cc−dabdc−ba]
                          (41)qvq∗=L(q)R(q∗)v或者R(q∗)L(q)v，他们是等价的=[a−b−c−dba−dccda−bd−cba][abcd−ba−dc−cda−b−d−cba]注意R(q∗)=R(q)T=[a2+b2+c2+d2ab−ab−cd+cdac+bd−ac−bdad−bc+bc−adab−ab+cd−cdb2+a2−d2−c2bc−ad−ad+bcbd+ac+bd+acac−bd−ac+bdbc+ad+ad+bcc2−d2+a2−b2cd+cd−ab−abad+bc−bc−adbd−ac+bd−accd+cd+ab+abd2−c2−b2+a2]

                          因为a2+b2+c2+d2=1，上式可以简化为：

                          (42)qvq∗=[100001−2c2−2d22bc−2ad2ac+2bd02bc+2ad1−2b2−2d22cd−2ab02bd−2ac2ab+2cd1−2b2−2c2]v

                          考虑只对三维向量进行旋转，对应的旋转矩阵可以写为：

                          (43)v′=[1−2c2−2d22bc−2ad2ac+2bd2bc+2ad1−2b2−2d22cd−2ab2bd−2ac2ab+2cd1−2b2−2c2]v

                          其中，如果考虑四元数与轴角的关系，则有

                          (44)a=cos⁡(θ/2),b=sin⁡(θ/2)ux,c=sin⁡(θ/2)uy,d=sin⁡(θ/2)uz

                          the equivalent pre-multiplied (to be used with column vectors) 3 × 3 rotation matrix is

                          (45)R=[1−2y2−2z22xy−2zw2xz+2yw2xy+2zw1−2x2−2z22yz−2xw2xz−2yw2yz+2xw1−2x2−2y2].

                          or display as

                          (46)R=[1−2(q22+q32)2(q1q2−q0q3)2(q0q2+q1q3)2(q1q2+q0q3)1−2(q12+q32)2(q2q3−q0q1)2(q1q3−q0q2)2(q0q1+q2q3)1−2(q12+q22)]，
                          (47)R=[a2+b2−c2−d22bc−2ad2bd+2ac2bc+2ada2−b2+c2−d22cd−2ab2bd−2ac2cd+2aba2−b2−c2+d2].

                          The parameter a may be called the scalar parameter, while ω→=(b,c,d) the vector parameter. In standard vector notation, the Rodrigues rotation formula takes the compact form

                          (48)qPq−1=(s+v)P(s−v)=(−v⋅P+sP+v×P)(s−v)=−sP×v−v×P×v+s2P+sv×P+vPv−vPs+sPv+v×P⋅v=s2P+2sv×P+(v⋅P)v−v×P×v

                          根据四元数乘法可得第3行。其中v×P⋅v=0，因为v×P和v垂直。其中−sP×v=sv×P，这根据叉乘的性质，可以得到第4行。另外，考虑如下等式：

                          P×(Q×P)=P×Q×P=P2Q−(P⋅Q)P

                          (49)qPq−1=s2P+2sv×P+(v⋅P)v−v×P×v=s2P+2sv×P+(v⋅P)v−v2P+(v⋅P)v=(s2−v2)P+2sv×P+2(v⋅P)v=(s2−v2)P+2sv×P+2(v2P−v×(P×v))=P+2sv×P+2(−v×(P×v))=P+2sv×P+2v×(v×P)

                          即：

                          (50)x→′=x→+2a(ω→×x→)+2(ω→×(ω→×x→))
                          (51)R=I+2a(ω→×)+2(ω→×)(ω→×)
                          xxxxxxxxxx
                          1
                          1
                          该公式出现在文献中。

                          Now every quaternion component appears multiplied by two in a term of degree two, and if all such terms are zero what is left is an identity matrix. This leads to an efficient, robust conversion from any quaternion – whether unit or non-unit – to a 3 × 3 rotation matrix. Given:

                          (52)n=||q||2=w2+x2+y2+z2s={0if n=02notherwise

                          we can calculate

                          (53)R=[1−s(yy+zz)s(xy−wz)s(xz+wy)s(xy+wz)1−s(xx+zz)s(yz−wx)s(xz−wy)s(yz+wx)1−s(xx+yy)]
